spans.content: Synthesis of novel hierarchical porous zeolitization ceramsite from industrial waste as efficient adsorbent for separation of ammonia nitrogen
Yuxin Chen, Ning Wang, Shengli An*, Changkun Cai, Jun Peng, Manyi Xie, Jihua Peng, Xiwen Song*

School of Materials and Metallurgy, Inner Mongolia University of Science and Technology, Baotou 014010, China  
Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region Key Laboratory of Advanced Ceramic Materials and Devices, Baotou 014010, China  
Key Laboratory of Green Extraction & Efficient Utilization of Light Rare-Earth Resources, Ministry of Education, Baotou 014010, China

Keywords:  
Solid waste  
Zeolite  
Ceramsite  
Water treatment  
Adsorption

In this study, a green process of high temperature sintering activation + hydrothermal reaction for the synthesis of novel zeolitization ceramsite from industrial wastes was designed. The synthesis process of zeolitization ceramsite was studied by XRD, SEM and FT-IR. The adsorption process of ceramsite was described by experiments and various kinetic model and isothermal adsorption model. The results show that the optimum preparation conditions were as follows: sintering temperature at

, NaOH concentration of 3 mol/L and time of 12 h. XRD and FT-IR showed that the modified ceramsite was loaded with cancrinite zeolite crystals, which was the main reason for the increase of specific surface area from
. Furthermore, the adsorption capacity of ammonia nitrogen increased from

. The adsorption mechanism of ammonia nitrogen by ceramsite was mainly ion exchange, which also accords with the structural characteristics of zeolite. The results are highly attractive for many industrial applications due to the simplicity and green of the synthesis procedure and remarkable adsorption properties.

The acceleration of industry and urbanization has led to an increase in the discharge of various types of sewage. Among them, ammonia nitrogen is one of the common pollutants in industrial and urban sewage, and it is also an important monitoring indicator of industrial sewage discharge in China. Ammonia nitrogen has a wide range of sources and large emissions, including petrochemical, metallurgy, and gas in the industrial field, fertilizer use in the agricultural field, animal excrement in the aquaculture field, and domestic sewage [1]. High concentrations of
is hazardous to various aquatic organisms [3]. The removal of ammonia nitrogen has been identified as a crucial issue.

Therefore, there is a drive to produce ceramsites for water treatment directly from solid waste rather than from natural minerals as a sustainable development strategy [4-6]. Mi et al. prepared ceramsites using fly ash and red mud as main raw materials [7]. Sun et al. prepared the ceramsite from fly ash as biological filter material to remove methane, the results indicated that the ceramsite showed higher methane

conductivity, which improved the adsorbed capacity of ceramsite [8]. Solid waste based ceramsite is mainly used as biological filter in the removing of ammonia nitrogen from wastewater. Currently, biological method is generally adopted in wastewater treatment plant, which is considered to be the most economical method for removing ammonia nitrogen [9]. However, biological processes are strict with the surrounding environment. Changes in temperature or ammonia nitrogen concentration can significantly affect the removal rate [10]. Studies have shown that the temperature of
reduction, the content of microorganisms will be reduced by about
[11]. Moreover, serious secondary environmental problems will be caused in biological processes, which is produced a large amount of sludge [12].

Adsorption method for ammonia nitrogen treatment is widely used because of its high efficiency, rapid and simplicity. Ceramsite is a potential adsorbent due to its high strength, high permeability and easy solid-liquid separation. Therefore, many researchers have also developed solid waste based ceramic adsorbent for the treatment of wastewater. Wang et al. [13] reported that the adsorption capacity of ceramsite prepared from sludge for

mmol/g, respectively. Jing et al. [14] developed porous ceramsite from diatomite and tungsten residue and found that its adsorption capacity for

. However, poor adsorption performance also hinders its extensive development. Hence, this study focuses on the zeolite molecular sieves with a large specific surface area and excellent ion exchange performance due to its unique pore structure of zeolite [15-19]. Whether the modified ceramics loaded with zeolite crystals can be obtained through reasonable modifier and modification method? Thus, the composite hierarchical porous ceramsites with ceramsite macropore, mesopore and molecular sieve micropore can be obtained, which is also subversive to the improvement of specific surface area and adsorption capacity of ceramsite. Actually, there have been many studies on the synthesis of zeolite powder from solid waste. Yang et al. synthesis of zeolite 4A by using fly ash as raw material fused with NaOH and/or

[20]. Cardoso et al. [21] synthesized zeolite from fly ash for wastewater treatment, the results show that it had a high adsorption capacity for total ammonia nitrogen. Although the zeolite powder synthesized by solid waste shows excellent adsorption performance, it is difficult to be used in fixed-bed reactors due to the disadvantages of tiny particles and low mechanical strength. However, there are few reports about synthesis of zeolitization ceramsites from solid waste. Hence, the ceramsites used in fixed-bed reactors from solid waste have been developed, moreover, the regeneration of zeolitization ceramsite method is simple. More interestingly, adsorbed ceramsites without regeneration even can be used for plant cultivation [22].

Therefore, in this study, the method of high-temperature sintering activation + hydrothermal reaction was proposed to prepare zeolitization ceramsites, which had the large specific surface area and high adsorption capacity of zeolite in addition to the granular shape and strength of ceramsites. Moreover, fly ash, as one of the solid wastes, which is generated by coal produces through thermal power generation or industrial combustion [23-25].

are main composition of the fly ash, which has potential raw materials for synthesis ceramsites [26-28]. Furthermore, iron tailings, as a common solid waste, have high silica content and are easy to form ceramsite skeleton, which is suitable for preparing materials with excellent compressive properties [29-32]. Meanwhile, the
contained in iron tailings can be used as cosolvent components. Thus, developing a synthetic method for zeolitization ceramsites from solid wastes would be more sustainable in practical applications.

The raw materials used in this study include two solid wastes, coal fly ash (provided by Power Plant, Baotou, China) and Bayan Obo iron tailing (provided by a research team at the Inner Mongolia University of Science and Technology, Baotou, China), the chemical compositions of two raw materials were shown in Table 1. All raw materials were used as received. All chemical reagents used in this study were analytically pure without any further purification. Quartz sand
, activated carbon, sodium silicate, ammonium chloride

are purchased from Macklin Co. Ltd., Shanghai, China. The ceramsite were prepared from raw materials following the weight percentages defined in Table 2. The addition of activated carbon was used as pore-forming agent, the sodium silicate was added as binders and to supplement Na sources for suitable zeolitization.
The typical preparation process of ceramsites consists of following. The zirconia balls and raw materials were mixing in a nylon bottle with a ball mill at a speed of
with a ball to powder ratio of 5:1, and anhydrous ethanol as the medium. After milling, the mixture was dried at
in air. The obtained well mixed powder was prepared into
spherical particles. The green ceramsites sintered in a furnace to produce ceramsite.
The prepared ceramsites were placed in a hydrothermal reactor and
sodium hydroxide solutions were added, respectively. Then, the hydrothermal reaction was proceeded at a temperature of

. After the reaction, the ceramsites was taken out and repeatedly washed with deionized water until it was neutral to obtain zeolitization ceramsite. The preparation flow chart of ceramsite was shown in Fig. 1.

sieves. The Xray photoelectron spectrum (XPS, Thermo, ESCALAB 250) was utilized over an Al-Kα X-ray source and the C 1 s signal was set at the position of

As zeolite ceramsite is a novel material used for adsorption of pollutants in water, various kinetic models and adsorption isothermal models were selected to describe its adsorption process. Among them, the adsorption kinetics models include pseudo-first-order model, pseudo-second-order model, Bangham model and Elovich model. Isothermal models include Langmuir model, Freundlich model, Dubinin-Radushkevich model and Temkin model.
Fig 2(a) Fig. 2(d) show SEM images of samples sintered at

, respectively. It can be seen from the figure that all samples exhibit three-dimensional penetrating porous structures. The formation of this structure ensures that wastewater can freely enter into the ceramsite to complete adsorption. Fig. 2(e) shows the XRD patterns of fly ash and samples sintered at different temperatures. As shown, the main phases of fly ash were
, mullite, calcium ferrite and iron oxide. Studies [33,34] have shown that mullite has high stability, it was difficult to be decomposed and released active

solution in the hydrothermal reaction. The XRD patterns of the as-sintered samples show that mullite and hedenbergite have disappeared, replaced by albite and diopside. This is mainly because mullite is a spherical particle wrapped by amorphous phase [35,36], which can be destroyed by the high temperature, causing the mullite decomposes into

and further reacts to albite. The water absorption and porosity of the sample increase first and then decrease with the increasing of sintering temperature, as shown in Fig. 2(f). The sample sintered at

with a low water absorption and porosity, which the main reason was the incomplete combustion of activated carbon at a low temperature. With the increase of sintering temperature, the pore-forming effect of activated carbon gradually elevated, increasing the water absorption rate and porosity of the sample. However, when the temperature elevated to
, the water absorption rate and porosity of the sample exhibit an obvious decreasing, mainly due to the densification of the sample at high temperature. Fig. 2(g) shows the amount of adsorbed
by samples sintered at different temperatures with an initial concentration of
by four samples show the same trend as porosity. The adsorption capacity was about
, which was at the equivalent level as the adsorption capacity of ceramsite reported by Ji et al. [37] and Li et al. [38].

Based on the above analysis, it can be found that high temperature plays two important roles in ceramsite sintering. Firstly, common sintering, the ceramsites present the basic structure of three-dimensional penetrating porous structures, that the water absorption rate was about
, which ensures the basic properties of ceramsite used as adsorption material. Secondly, activization, mullite in fly ash was destroyed during high-temperature sintering, resulting
were released and transformed into albite. Therefore, the optimum

was used as the basic ceramsite for subsequent zeolitization.
Fig. 3 shows the phases composition and microstructure of zeolitization ceramsites with different sodium hydroxide concentrations. Fig. 3 (a) is the SEM image of the ceramsite treated with

NaOH solution, compared with the basic ceramsites in Fig. 2 (c), the three-dimensional pores structure in the original ceramsite can still be distinctly observed. Nevertheless, it was inferred that the specific surface area shows a significant increase due to a large number of fine crystals appear. It can be found from the XRD patterns in Fig. 3(d) that

indicated that the successful formation of ceramsite loaded the zeolite. Moreover, it was confirmed that the feasibility of high temperature activation. Nevertheless, the diffraction patterns of sodium aluminum silicate and

indicated that it was an incomplete zeolitization process, which was due to the low concentration of NaOH. The same situation also appeared in the Ren et al.'s study [39]. Fortunately, the amount adsorbed
even with incomplete zeolitization. Fig. 3(b) is the SEM image of the ceramsite treated with

NaOH solution. The figure shows many fine crystals growing in the ceramsite, which makes the ceramsite exhibit a more complex porous structure. The XRD pattern in Fig. 3(d) shows that the zeolitization ceramsite was composed of cancrinite, diopside and ferric oxide. The increase of NaOH concentration promoted the conversion of sodium silicate aluminate and
to zeolite. In addition, the high alkalinity

cannot be absorbed into the channels freely [40]. It is because of the part of cancrinite was transformed into sodalite due to the high concentration of NaOH solution, that affects the amount adsorbed of
Fig. 4 shows the phases composition and microstructure of zeolitization ceramsites at different hydrothermal temperature with

NaOH solution, indicating the hydrothermal temperature has a significant effect on the hydrothermal products of ceramsite. As can be seen in Fig. 4(a)-Fig. 4(e), with the increasing of hydrothermal temperature, a large number of fine crystals gradually grew in the sample. The increase in temperature was conducive to crystal nucleation and growth. The samples had a transition from the simple three-dimensional pore
structure of the basic ceramsite to the more complex porous structure. According to the XRD patterns in Fig. 4(f), the watershed of the influence of temperature on hydrothermal process was
. When the temperature was lower than
and albite indicating that the zeolitization of ceramsite was not complete. When the temperature exceeded

and albite completely disappear in the as-prepared ceramsites which was probably because that the energy can be provided by the high temperature for growing of zeolite crystals. Fig. 4(g) shows that the amount of adsorbed
of samples increases first and then decreases, the maximum value is
. It was worth noting that the amount of adsorbed
decreased slightly when the hydrothermal temperature was
. This may be due to the collapse of the pore structure of the zeolite at higher temperature, resulting in a decrease in its adsorption capacity [41].
In order to further study the effect of zeolitization on the porous structure, the

adsorption and desorption curve of the sample before and after modification were analyzed, as shown in Fig. 5. The calculation results of specific surface area and pore volume were listed in Table 3. It shows that the specific surface area was

The increase in specific surface area was mainly attributed to the formation of cancrinite crystals, which belongs to zeolite family with a developed pore structure. FT-IR was used to analyze the samples before and after modification, as shown in Fig. 6. In the spectrum of ceramsite, the infrared adsorption peaks were located near
, which attributed to the symmetrical stretching vibration peaks of Si-O, Si-O-Si, T-O-Si
or Al) bonds [42]. The spectrum of zeolitization ceramsite was different from the ceramsite, the infrared adsorption peaks at
are belonged to mixed vibrations of the framework of tetrahedra, which means the formation of zeolite structures [43]. The peak at
is corresponding to stretching vibrations of aluminosilicate framework [44,45]. The peaks were located near
hydrogen-bond bending vibration and stretching vibrations.

Cancrinite, as one of zeolite family, has abundant pore structure. Fig. 7 shows the evolution mechanism of molecular structure during phase transition. Fig. 7(a) and Fig. 7 (d) are lattice cells of albite, while Fig. 7(b) and Fig. 7 (e) are lattice cells of cancrinite. It can be seen from
the figure that 12-Ring was formed by
sharing oxygen atom at the same vertex. Then the two 12-Rings were connected by
sharing oxygen atom, thus forming a cancrinite lattice cell [46]. First of all, due to the presence of 12-Ring, a
channel was formed in cancrinite lattice cell, as shown in Fig. 7(c), (f). The size of the channel was larger than the ionic radius of
was allowed to enter the channel freely. In addition, 12-Ring was connected by
sharing oxygen atoms with each other. Due to the different valence of
, alkaline metals or alkaline earth metals were needed to balance the valence. Generally, there are

in cancrinite molecules, but these ions are not strongly combined with cancrinite cages, resulting in excellent ion exchange of cancrinite [47]. Hence, based on the above two reasons, the specific surface area and adsorption capacity for
of the ceramsite after hydrothermal modification were greatly improved.

of ammonia nitrogen almost shows a linear increase. This phenomenon is attributed to an increase in the adsorption site by increasing in the amount of adsorbent. Meanwhile, the high ammonia nitrogen concentration helps
enter the interior of the ceramsite, thus increasing the adsorption capacity. When the dosage up to

, the number of available total active point sites increase to an optimal level [48]. There is no obvious benefit of improving the removal rate of ammonia nitrogen bring by increasing the dosage of adsorbent. Hence, when the quantity of ceramsite was greater than

, the increase rate of ammonia nitrogen removal rate tends to be gentle. However, the adsorption performance decreases with the increase of ceramsite addition, which may be related to the relative decrease of
adsorbent, causing a weakening of the diffusion driving force of
Fig. 9 indicates the influence of different initial concentrations on ammonia nitrogen removal rate and amount of adsorbed

. The adsorption capacity of ceramsite increased, while the ammonia nitrogen removal efficiency decreased with the increasing of initial concentration of solution. This may suggest that there is a low mass flow rate of ions due to low ammonia nitrogen concentration, causing there are extra active sites to be utilized on zeolite ceramics. Thus, the adsorption under this situation is more dependent on ammonia nitrogen concentration [29]. However, with the increase of ammonia concentration in solution, the formation of
concentration gradient between solid phase and liquid phase, correspondingly increases the driving force of

tends to flow into the interior of ceramicite, resulting in the increase of ceramicite adsorption capacity [34]. Meanwhile, some researcher found that ion migration becomes less random and then follows electrostatic attraction dynamics between the absorbent and the absorbent at higher concentrations [50].
Fig. 10 shows the effect of adsorption time on the ammonia nitrogen adsorption. Within

, the adsorption capacity and ammonia nitrogen removal efficiency of ceramsite increased rapidly, which was mainly due to the high initial ammonia nitrogen concentration of the solution and the large number of ceramsite adsorption sites, causing the most
was adsorbed by the ceramsite in a short time. At
of the maximum adsorption capacity, and the ammonia nitrogen removal rate is

. The adsorption rate of zeolite ceramsite is faster than some recently reported granular adsorbents [37,51], which is mainly due to the larger diffusion rate brought about by the macropores and mesopores of the hierarchically porous ceramsite. With

, the concentration of ammonia nitrogen in solution and the adsorption site of ceramsite continued to decrease, the adsorption rate gradually slows down until equilibrium. This phenomenon can be explained by the following points: First, the initial stage of adsorption is mainly mass transfer through ion concentration gradient between solid and liquid [52]. Second, the stage of slow adsorption rate describes the end of adsorption, and slight desorption of

ions adsorbed by ceramsite may occur corresponding to the ionic equilibrium between solid and liquid phases. Finally, slower and more gradual growth corresponds to local diffusion within the ceramsite, which continues until active site saturation [50]. Other studies have reported similar trends [53].

Pseudo-first-order model, Pseudo-second-order model, Bangham model and Elovich model were used to study the Kinetic model of ammonia nitrogen adsorption by zeolitization ceramsite, the results were shown in Fig. 11 and Table 4. The fitting parameters of Pseudo-first-order model and Pseudo-second-order model were 0.9798 and
Fig. 10. Effect of adsorption time on the ammonia nitrogen adsorption.
calculated by the Pseudo-second-order model is larger than the Pseudo-first-order model, which is closer to the experimental value. It can be confirmed that the adsorption process of

was better described by the Pseudo-second-order model. Likewise, it is inferred that part of the ammonia nitrogen is fixed in the ceramsite by chemical adsorption [50]. Meanwhile, the fitting parameter

of Elovich model was 0.9130, which was greater than 0.9, indicating that chemical adsorption was involved in the adsorption process of ammonia nitrogen by ceramsite [54]. Combined with the above structure analysis, cancrinites were synthesized during the modification of ceramsite. Therefore, it can be concluded that ion exchange must be involved in the adsorption process of ceramsite. In addition, the fitting parameter
of Bangham model was 0.9925, indicating that there was a pore diffusion mechanism in the adsorption process of ceramic particles, which also accords with the adsorption mechanism of zeolite.

Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin and Dubinin-Radushkevich models were used for studying the adsorption isotherms based on the experimental data in Fig. 8. The results were shown in Fig. 12 and Table 5. The fitting parameters of Langmuir model and Freundlich model were 0.9983 and 0.9563, respectively. This indicates that the adsorption behavior of ammonia nitrogen on zeolitization ceramsites can be better described by the Langmuir model. The adsorption belongs to uniform monolayer adsorption [55], and the maximum adsorption capacity is
value was greater than 1, indicating that chemical adsorption was involved in the adsorption process [56], which was consistent with the above analysis results. In addition, in the D-R model, the
value defined as average free energy of adsorption was
Fig. 11. Kinetic model of ammonia nitrogen adsorption by zeolitization ceramsite. (a) Pseudo-first-order model. (b) Pseudo-second-order model. (c) Bangham model. (d) Elovich model.
Table 4 Kinetic parameters of ammonia nitrogen adsorption by modified ceramsite.

suggests that the adsorption process mainly includes ion exchange [57]. In order to analyze the adsorption mechanism of zeolitization ceramsite, XPS analysis was conducted on the samples, as shown in Fig. 13. Moreover, Fig. 14 shows the schematic diagram of the

preparation and adsorption process of ceramsite. Fig. 13(a) and Fig. 13 (b) show XPS scanning of samples before and after adsorption. Na, O, Al and Si exist in both samples, confirming the formation of zeolite phase. The raw ceramsites were sintered at
, leading the ceramsite was strengthened and mullite in the raw material was activated. The ceramsite was hydrothermally modified with

solution to obtain porous ceramsite loaded with cancrinite crystals, which was a composite hierarchical porous ceramsite with macropores, mesopores and zeolite micropores. This will produce two effects: Firstly, because the zeolite crystal is composed of silicon oxygen tetrahedron and aluminum oxygen tetrahedron, forming a three-dimensional skeleton structure after expansion, causing the formation of many holes and pores, thus, the ions or molecules less than the aperture can be absorbed [58]. This conclusion is consistent with the adsorption kinetics fitting results above. Secondly, the existence of aluminum-oxygen tetrahedron makes zeolite framework have good ion exchange performance [59], which can be confirmed by XPS results. Fig. 13(c) and Fig. 13(d) show the XPS scanning spectra of Na 1 s. It is noteworthy that the signal of Na 1 s of the sample after adsorption was significantly reduced at
compared with that before adsorption, which also meant that
had been ion exchanged. Meanwhile, the characteristic peak of N 1 s appears near
after adsorption, as shown in Fig. 13(e) and Fig. 13(f). For the O1s spectra of sample before adsorption, the bonding energy of O 1 s was split into three peaks of O1 for Fe-O bond
Fig. 12. Isothermal adsorption curve model of ammonia nitrogen adsorption by zeolitization ceramsite. (a) Langmuir model. (b) Freundlich model. (c) Temkin model. (d) Dubinin-Radushkevich model.
Table 5 Adsorption parameters of isothermal adsorption of ammonia nitrogen by modified ceramsite.
Al bond (531.35 eV) [5]. After reacting thoroughly, the energy and proportion of O1 hardly changed, indicating that
did not participate in the adsorption of ammonia nitrogen. However, the O1 of 531.35 eV which transformed to

, thereby weakening their chemical bond and reducing the binding energy of central elements. Combined with the above analysis of adsorption tests, it was further proved that the adsorption mechanism of ammonia nitrogen by modified ceramsite was mainly ion exchange. It shows that the adsorption of ammonia nitrogen by zeolite ceramsite does not completely depend on large specific surface area, which is also the main reason for the good adsorption performance of zeolite ceramsite although the specific surface area has not been significantly improved [50]. Therefore, there are three main mechanisms for the adsorption of ammonia nitrogen ions by the ceramsite. The first is ion exchange, that is,
enters the zeolite structure to replace
enters the channels of the zeolite structure. The third is that the
adsorbed by porous structure of ceramsite, as shown in Fig. 14.

Table 6 shows the comparison of effects of adsorbents from different sources on adsorption of ammonia nitrogen from water, it was found that the adsorption capacity of ammonia nitrogen of zeolite ceramsite proposed in this study increases by about 10 times compared with that of ordinary ceramsite. Meanwhile, the adsorption performance of
Fig. 13. XPS analysis of modification ceramsite (a), (c), (e), (g) and modification ceramsite after adsorption (b), (d), (f), (h).

ammonia nitrogen is significantly superior to that of granular adsorbent synthesized from zeolite. Compared with biochar adsorbent synthesized from waste, the zeolite ceramsite synthesized in this study also has an obvious advantage in removing ammonia nitrogen. However, it was slightly lower than synthetic zeolite powder, mainly because zeolite powder has a larger specific surface area and was easier to complete adsorption. In addition, cancrinite only has a one-dimensional pore structure, and the adsorption capacity and efficiency of ammonia

nitrogen are lower than those of zeolite A, zeolite X and zeolite Y with three-dimensional structure [60]. Nevertheless, the synthesis of zeolite A, zeolite X and zeolite Y has stricter requirements on the impurity content and Si/Al ratio of the system. The ceramicsites loaded with cancrinite zeolite were prepared from fly ash and iron tailings without any purification, but the remarkable adsorption capacity was still obtained, which was cheaper and more in line with green synthesis.
Fig. 14. Schematic diagram for synthesizing of modified ceramsites and adsorption mechanism of ammonia nitrogen.

spans.content: Comparison of the adsorption capacity of various adsorbents for removal of

In this study, ceramsite loaded with zeolite crystal was successfully prepared by high temperature sintering activation + hydrothermal synthesis, the main finding of the study is summarized as following:
(1) The optimum preparation conditions were as follows: sintering temperature at
. XRD and FT-IR showed that the modified ceramsite was loaded with cancrinite zeolite crystals, resulting the specific surface area increased from
, adsorption capacity to ammonia nitrogen increased from
(2) The adsorption process was described by a variety of models, combined with XPS analysis, the results showed that the adsorption of ammonia nitrogen by zeolite ceramsite was mainly
ion exchange. The maximum adsorption capacity of ceramsite was
, which was 10 times that of ordinary ceramsite.

(3) While ensuring the remarkable adsorption properties, the zeolitization ceramsite avoids the difficulty of solid-liquid separation of traditional zeolite powder, that are highly attractive for many industrial applications.
